Это история про то, как в мультяшной галактике, заселвенной зайцами-космодесантниками, пчелами-коммунистами и улитками-диджеями Злобный Космический Властелин сражается с Галактическим Сенатам за отстаивание своих злодейских прав: таких как разжигание галактических войн ради собственного развлечения и парковка в неположенном месте.

Вообще, неожиданно приятный образчик шпиллева, рад, что его приобрел. Не смотря на ранний доступ творение выглядит вполне себе цельным, по крайней мере после последнего апдейта, заметно улучшившего интерфейс и сделавшего играбильной третью фракцию (хотя, вот что мне не нравится - так это то, что фракции открываются одна за другой в случае победы в кампании, а не доступны на выбор с самого начала). Кампания здесь не следует сценарию, мы просто выбираем миссии в том или ином секторе (три сектора, по числу рас-фракций), собирая с них награды и бонусы, делающие империю сильнее после каждой успешной операции. Все это нужно, чтобы выжить в миссиях с более высокой сложностью, когда легкие задания в секторе закончатся. В конце концов откроется финальная миссия, успех в которой во много зависит от того, как хорошо удалось прокачать империю бонусами с предыдущих заданий и насколько правильно подобраны перки и экипировка. Все это время наши главные враги - Галактический Сенат (увы, в отличие от Палпатина, наш Тиран в нем не заседает, а очень даже активно ему противостоит) тоже повышают свое влияние в секторах, и если в каком-то отдельном секторе им удастся добиться максимального влияния, это будет означать поражение - так что миссии приходится выбирать еще и с учетом необходимости снижать влияние Сената. Надо сказать, не смотря на то, что игра заявлена как незатейливое казуальное развлечение и имеет действительно простую базовую механику, привести силы Космического Тирана к победе оказалось достаточно непросто. Впрочем, тут имеются и некоторые rouge-light элементы, которую могут облегчить кампанию после нескольких неудачных попыток - успешно пройденные миссии открывают не только бонусы для данного конкретного прохождения, но и постоянные возможности, вроде новых кораблей, полководцев и карт-операций (разыгрываются за отдельный ресурс в свой ход, как карты в различных образчиках ККИ, и делают что-нибудь полезное - эффекты бывают весьма разнообразны). Это не то, чтобы однозначно усиливает игрока после каждой кампании, но дает множество новых опций на пути к победе. Вообще, игра выглядит как предельно оказуаленная версия глобальной космической стратегии, но по своей сути больше похожа на настолку - имеется поле, разбитое на клетки, мы пошагово перемещаем по нему войска, захватываем эти самые клетки, различные виды которых дают нам различные бонусы и ресурсы, что позволяет строить больше армий, дабы захватывать еще больше клеток и, в конце концов, выполнить задачу конкретной карты (это может быть захват большей ее части, накопление нужного количества какого-то из ресурсов, удержание двух из трех контрольных точек и т.п.). Содержимое клеток и то, что они дают, отличается достаточным разнообразием, надо заметить. Некоторые просто дают приток ресурсов, некоторые облегчают захват новых планет (захват проходит через механизм осады - игрок раз в ход бросает кубик и снижает оборону осаждаемой территории - территория подчинится, когда оборона упадет до нуля), захваченные тюрьмы дают командиров, которые возглавляют наши флоты, есть вещи, которые дают большой бонус, но самоуничтожаются через определенное число ходов и т.д.

Бои здесь проходят в реальном времени, без перемещения кораблей по полю - они выстраиваются друг напротив друга и принимаются методично обмениваться огнем, без возможности напрямую управлять ими. И это на практике гораздо увлекательнее, чем звучит. Игрок влияет на бой в основном расстановкой войск - это имеет значение, поскольку некоторые способности воздействуют на юниты в соседних клетках, - и тратя восполняющийся запас энергии на активацию спецспособностей своих кораблей. Как мне кажется, в данном случае этого все же достаточно, чтобы сохранять вовлеченность игрока в сражение, не смотря на отсутствие прямого контроля.

Из ресурсов есть деньги, на которые мы покупаем корабли для флота, есть очки исследования, благодаря которым улучшаются отдельные классы наших кораблей, есть кристаллы, на которые разыгрываются уже упомянутые ранее карты. Еще отдельного упоминания заслуживает шкала тирании - этот показатель необходимо поддерживать выше определенного минимума, иначе наступит поражение в миссии. Шкала убывает каждый ход - издержки народного недовольства, как объясняет это игра. Как ее пополнить? Завоевывать новые планеты, уничтожать вражеские корабли, стараться не проигрывать битвы и делать правильные, внушающие ужас и трепет выборы во всплывающих в процессе завоеваний эвентах. Пока наши войска с песнями и лихими посвистами несутся по галактике, причиняя добро и нанося справедливость, с нашим уровнем тирании будет полный порядок. Это, очевидно, заставляет игрока постоянно расширять подконтрольную ему территорию. Надо сказать, если бы это была классическая 4Х-стратегия, я был бы далеко не в восторге от подобного подхода, поскольку я не являюсь фанатом гипер-агрессивного стиля прохождения в космических стратегиях. Собственно, наверное в этом кроется одна из основных причин моих достаточно сложных отношений с данным жанром, поскольку меня во многих его образчиках совершенно не привлекает то, что для большинства составляет самый цимес - экспансия. Если я играю в глобальную стратегию, то как правило, я делаю это предельно неторопливо, избегая войн и не шибко горя желанием расширять владения - мне куда больше импонирует наводить порядок на уже имеющейся территории, а не захватывать новую без остановки. Однако, Space Tyrant, как я уже сказал, не особо-то и тянет на 4Х-стратегию. На уже завоеванных территориях заняться особо нечем, экспансия - это главная, и фактически единственная составляющая геймплея. И вот поскольку от этой самой экспансии нас ничто здесь больше не отвлекает, к такому подходу у меня нет никаких особых претензий - как раз-таки здесь непрерывная погоня за новыми завоеваниями доставляет немало удовольствия. Выдержанная стилистика это лишний раз подчеркивает, конечно же.

Говоря про эту самую стилистику... Мне кажется, очень многое в этой игре работает именно благодаря поддержанию соответствующего настроя и стиля. Мы играем за предельно карикатурное галактическое Зло, с ощутимым налетом мультяшности. У нас есть большая красная кнопка, при нажатии на которую мы тыкаем своим костлявым пальцем в карту и посылаем "луч добра", уничтожающий пару кораблей противника. Способность вполне полезная с точки зрения геймплея, но главное - что все здесь выполнено именно в таком духе. Планеты на карте обвешаны всевозможными непропорционально-гигантскими надстройками в соответствии со специализацией мира, описания эвентов при захвате новых планет восхитительны в своей гипертрофированной "бугагашности" и так далее. Обитающие в галактике расы, опять же, заслуживают отдельного упоминания. Есть, соответственно, зайцы-космодесантники - перекаченные, брутальные, пушистые зайки, решающие все проблемы астероидной бомбардировкой. Есть хлипкие, но многочисленные и сплоченные пчелы-коммунисты, чьи корабли стилизованы под соты, а командиры готовы за Вождя и Партию порвать кого угодно, особенно акул межпланетного империализьма. А есть техно-слизни - называются они так не потому, что любят технику, а потому что любят техно. И вообще музыку. И зажигать под музыку. У них даже флагманы оборудованы колонками, потому что настоящему диджею вакуум - не помеха!

В общем и целом, весь здешний игровой процесс преподносится в достаточно камерной и при этом динамичной манере - итого у нас имеется простая по механике, но вполне имеющая тактическую глубину вещица. В сочетании с юмором и отлично поддерживаемой стилистикой мультяшного космического злодея - неожиданно достойное творение. На какое-то время затягивает, надо признать.

With its store front claim of delivering a "fast-paced roguelike-lite 5X" experience, chunky UI, and colorful cartoonish graphics, Space Tyrant may at first glance seem like just another one of those hyper-casual mobile games that we're seeing more and more of on Steam these days; but beneath the veneer lies a brilliantly conceived game that, despite lacking the depth of many 4X games that fans of the genre celebrate, delivers an entertaining experience that can be just as satisfying.

I've always had a soft spot for games that let me be the bad guy. Space Tyrant endeavors to join the ranks of titles like Dungeon Keeper, Evil Genius, and Overlord by casting the player in the role of the ultimate... well... Space Tyrant. You'll find no diplomatic standing screen here. There will be no trade routes. You will not be tweaking your economy (unless brutally oppressing your hapless citizens to increase their productivity counts as "tweaking"). You will foster no alliances, shaky or otherwise. There will be no negotiation. The galaxy will either submit to your will, or you will destroy it with your lasers and missiles. Or maybe you'll be the one who gets destroyed by lasers and missiles. Actually, that's probably what will happen.

The premise was immediately enticing to me, but even though my curators were recommending it and all of the other internet buzz surrounding the game was positive, I held back. The reason was simple: "Fast-paced" and "4X" are mutually exclusive terms in my world. I like my 4X games with layers upon layers of depth. I enjoy being able to wrest control of the universe from my enemies using strength, wit, and guile (along with a healthy dose of economic min-maxing). My current all-time favorite of the genre is Distant Worlds, and I've long since decided that if a 4X game can't deliver that sort of deep experience, then I simply don't have time for it.

Thankfully, after having been practically browbeaten by my peers into buying the game, I discovered that Space Tyrant is far more than it seems on the surface. A campaign plays out almost like a series of board games, if board games could be randomly generated. I won't get into the mechanical specifics of the game, as so many other reviews have already covered that; suffice it to say that despite the seemingly simple premise of "just blow everything up to win," there are tons of strategic and tactical options available to the player over the course of a campaign. Will you prioritize conquering crystal worlds in order to utilize your most powerful cards? Or will you favor wealthy worlds in the early game to quickly bolster your fleets? Or perhaps you will focus on tech worlds, so that even your most meager fleet will be able to deal with hordes of ill-equipped enemies.

You will need to do all three to succeed, but how you choose to prioritize objectives based on enemy movement, playfield layout, and other RNG factors will make or break you. Yes, you can play this game quick and dirty; but if you're not paying attention, the Galactic Senate will end you. Or the RNG. Or the space sharks. Yeah, there are space sharks. With lasers on their heads. Because why wouldn't a space shark have a laser on its head?

So in closing, if you're like me and find yourself hesitant to try this game based on any sort of 4X bias, just stop it. Stop being a 4X elitist. You should be ashamed. I know I am.

This game is not even finished yet, and it's already awesome. Buy it and play it already. Keep your Stellaris wiki open in the background if it helps keep you sane, just play this game.

[h1]Video, in case you'd rather watch[/h1]

[h1]About The Game[/h1]
Space Tyrant is an interesting mix of 4x strategy game and roguelite. Your aim is to conquer the galaxy: you move your ships through the universe to capture the planets, combat enemies and encounter all sorts of random events as you keep capturing new bases.

The game process is the following: right now, you get to choose a side, then you have the “universe” map shown: you can assault one of three galaxies, while the fourth one is being locked away. Then, you are moved towards the galaxy where you have to complete a specific objective: capturing planets, acquiring wealth, researching new technologies. You choose a commander which determines what kind of a special ability your ship is going to have. It also gives you some mini-objectives for the mission that can influence your play style: completing them makes you stronger, you can get a special powerful cards that can be used on the galaxy map. You direct your fleets through “paths” between planets, and if they encounter another fleet – the battle starts.

[h1]The Battles[/h1]
The battle itself is pretty simple: two fleets stay opposite to each other and exchange fire. The targets are chosen randomly. Each of your ships has a special ability that they can use on the click. . (each side has only 4 purchasable ships (+ a few bonus stronger ones), but those 4 get upgraded as you play, adding stats / improving their abilities). So yes, while this sounds simple, there’s plenty of space for decision making. 

If you got confused by that – that’s totally cool. In fact, this is what makes the game interesting. The mix of different things that you can do. What makes it even more impressive is the fact how tutorials are made: those are the sequences of small videos that gradually introduce you into the game as you play. [h1]Cons[/h1]
Only a few things hurt my experience: At the moment of writing this review, there’s no difference between clicking with left / right button. So when you pick an ability (i.e. death ray) and want to cancel using it – right click will actually trigger it the same way as left click.

I’ve lost one game 6v2 when 2 enemies didn’t do much damage, but kept regenerating shields and my fighters picked targets in worst possible way: 3 were firing at one ship, 3 – at another. [h1]Summary[/h1]

Every mission playthrough takes from somewhere around half an hour for smaller maps to an hour and a half for bigger scenarios. Overall, this is one of those “I’ll play 5 more minutes” games that eats your time at tremendous rate because it’s so engaging. Plenty of unlockable content and events even in the current early access state, I can confidently recommend the game for its gameplay to those of you who want to experience cosmic strategies but don’t have days to waste on a single battle scenario.

This is a 4X-Lite game with card-based powerups and blistering real-time fleet battles which last only a matter of seconds, with fighters, laser beams and explosions galore!

This review has been chopped in places to make it fit here. Please [url=http://wp.me/p8lFHx-5uL]visit the original review here[/url] with all the screenshots etc.

To give you a rough outline of what this is about, you take on missions to conquer networks of planets. Each turn you send your little spaceship fleets to battle with the enemy fleets on the adjacent planets and then once you’ve defeated them you can invade the planet with a big dice. You get gold income from conquered planets which you can use to purchase new ships for your fleets, and crystal planets increase the number of points you can use to play your powerup cards which are added to your ‘hand’ on each turn. Domination is the ultimate goal, of course.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

There is a LOT happening all the time in this game, so I’m going to try and explain this with screenshots.

First you choose your faction. As you can see, I haven’t even unlocked the second one yet.

Then you select a mission. Each has a 4-star rating depending on difficulty. Take note of the ‘SENATE CONTROL’ boxes. I found to my cost that if those four boxes fill up with red triangles, it’s Game Over, so don’t just blindly go for the easiest missions like I did. When you successfully complete a mission you get a skull. Fill everything up with skulls and you beat the campaign.

So when you start a mission you’re told what your goals are to win. There are various different objectives each time, like conquering special planets, amassing gold, conquering a certain percentage of the galaxy etc.

At first you have only your home planet and a small fleet. The best thing to do is go on the attack immediately! Move to the next planet where an enemy fleet is orbiting and the battle screen will open.

Note the Death Ray over on the right, it measures your Tyranny. It goes up and down depending on how quickly you’re expanding your empire and obliterating any fleets that dare to join the Senate. If any of your fleets stay in one place for too long – well, at all actually – you’ll pay the price here. You have to keep relentlessly crushing agitators and moving on to keep the Death Ray topped up. If it drops too low it’s Game Over – not just the mission, but the whole campaign! If you get it up high enough then a big red button appears and you can zap a few enemy ships with the big pointy finger in the sky!

The cards at the bottom of the screen can be played at any time during your turn. [chopped]

[screenshots of battle]

The trick, of course, is to never go into a battle that you can’t win! If you have a bigger fleet going into the battle then you’ll (nearly) always win.

Battles are fast and furious! Look at all this! These battles generally only last about 15-30 seconds, it’s intense. Blink and you’ll miss it!

... and eventually you’ll get a bigger fleet:

Once you’ve defeated the enemy fleet you can then capture the planet for your empire by rolling the dice. [chopped]

When the planet is conquered you get a few choices of planet exploration, some have good outcomes, others bad. [chopped]

So you continue like that, conquering one planet after another. You can release new fleets by conquering prison planets, hiring a new commander from your home planet with 300 gold, or get them for other reasons. Like I said there’s all kinds of stuff going on.

Hopefully you’ll eventually reach your objective, complete the mission and receive your reward and a perk, then it’s on to the next mission.

All in all, it plays like the turn-based strategy version of DOOM – you’re rewarded by pushing forward relentlessly and taking undue risks. Glorious death is rarely in vain as you’ve softened up the enemy for your next wave.

[h1]False Sense Of Security[/h1]

The AI is absolutely diabolical! And I love it! Three times now my campaign has been suddenly and unexpectedly halted in mid-flow while I wasn’t paying proper attention. Each time I was kicking arse and taking names in my missions, vanquishing foes left, right and centre. Then they stabbed me in the back. The first time an enemy fleet sneaked up behind me and took my home planet while I was too busy cutting a swathe of devastation elsewhere. The second time I got busy making my home planet into an iron fortress, ignoring my Death Ray which plummeted until the galaxy rebelled and it was Game Over again. The third time I really thought I had everything covered this time. Nope. It turned out that I’d picked the wrong missions and allowed the Senate to take over a sector without me even trying to defend it!

Each time this happened you’d think I would storm off in a huff, but no. I was grinning from ear to ear and raring to go again, shaking my fist in the air like Grandpa Simpson. There’s nothing quite like discovering something genuinely surprising in a game. Fabulous.
Crushed!

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

The list of things I love about this game is pretty long, but right at the top of it is the way the learning curve is handled. From the moment you start playing the fun never lets up. At first it’s just joyous chaos, with things popping up all over the place, decisions to make, tips to follow and generally not knowing what the hell is going on. Mad as a box of frogs. Slowly but surely you get the hang of it, and before you know it you’re planning routes, counting ships, calculating your odds and turning into a proper Tyrant. Until the AI blindsides you, of course. Haha!

There are no overall difficulty settings, it just becomes increasingly difficult as you progress, with one to four-star missions. The more experience you get, the further your campaign will go.

[h1]Value[/h1]

There are three main factions to play. When you beat a full campaign then the next faction is unlocked and you can start all over again with, I assume, different powers and so forth. The third faction is not ready yet, and will be a main feature of the full release after Early Access. With that said, each mission takes a couple of hours to get through – and the time really flies! It’s going to take me many hours to even beat the first campaign so there’s more than enough to be getting on with already. This feels like a full, complete game. I’ve found no bugs, no annoyances but plenty of gameplay. It’s definitely worth full price even at this stage. The EA phase here is just for adding extra goodies to the pile.

[h1]Steam[/h1]

There are no trading cards or achievements yet but they will be in the full release. Please don’t let this put you off in any way. There is personal achievement to be had in beating these missions, never mind about Steam.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

I’ve played enough slow, tedious turn-based strategy games to know that this one stands out due to the fast-paced, exciting combat that keeps you constantly engaged and trying to push the boundaries of your power against a fairly clever AI. It’s challenging and addictive while the gameplay is intuitive once you get into the swing of it. The artwork and music make it even better, and the native Linux version is the cherry on the delicious cake.

[h1]Aftermath[/h1]

After 60+ hours of trying I finally managed to beat the first campaign! Yay! I had to beat the final five-star mission and capture the Senate’s home planet to do it. I’m a proper, legit Tyrant now I thought, so I started a new campaign and decided to be cocky and go for the enemy’s home planet. This was a one-star mission, easy peasy right? Well, I was brought crashing down to Earth when my own home planet was invaded. It just goes to show, a Tyrant must be vigilant at all times, there are always agitants plotting and scheming behind your back. Seriously though, there is endless replay value here – ruling the galaxy once doesn’t guarantee a repeat performance.

Here, you choose which mission to undertake, your goal being to conquer at least one sector before the Galactic Senate does the same, then take the war to the homeworld of the Galactic Senate itself.
	After selecting a mission, the real gameplay begins. Space Tyrant is turn based, and operates on a nodal movement system; your fleets only orbit planets and can only move between them per predesignated lanes. Although mission objectives vary, you'll be accomplishing all of them through military conquest. Tyrants have no time for diplomacy. Your fleets resolve planetary sieges through dice rolls. You roll a D6 until the defense score of the planet is zero. This is familiar territory, be prepared for frustratingly low rolls during critical sieges. Before the siege begins, of course, you must rout the defenders.
	Combat is mostly autonomous. Your vessels select their own targets and fire at will. Your participation is limited to the deployment of tactics and ship abilities. You recieve a tactical ability from a choice of three at the beginning of combat, sometimes useful, sometimes not so much. Each class of vessel for each race has an ability which can be activated for energy, a recharging resource. The combat reminds me of old Ogre Battle games. Although smart ability usage can turn the tide of a battle, combats tend to be won or lost beforehand. Winning these battle grants experience for your commander, allowing them to level up and lead larger fleets.
	Planets provide you with gold income, research, mana, or special bonuses, such as new commanders or additional siege dice. Cash is used to purchase warships, research unlocks new technology (all of them military), and mana is used to play cards. You draw one card per turn, and you can play them on the campaign map for a wide variety of effects. When you initially conquer a planet, you 'explore' it. This exploration plays out as a choose your own adventure dialogue box. These choice outcomes can be good or negative, and can give your Tyrant traits which influence future explorations. This is where a great deal of the humor of the game is derived. You are brutal intergalactic Tyrant, so your choices are often variations of 'nuke them' or 'throw them in the torture box'. 
	My primary frustrations with the title mostly came from the fact that the only options to interact with the environment (beyond the rare but powerful planet powers) involve your military, but your fleets only move one node per turn. Enemy planets can run projects to disrupt your empire, such as economic sanctions or propaganda, which can only be stopped by conquest. Your own planets can also rebel, again, requiring one of your fleets to painfully and slowly backtrack one node per turn, wasting an astonishing amount of time. Enemy planets can begin projects to cripple your empire from anywhere, but you may not have fleets in position to respond. I would have loved to see some way to respond to these projects. Bribes, assassinations, and counter intelligence all would be thematic options for the player to have.
	Space Monsters are also present and caused me some strife. Space Monsters are powerful leviathans that protect valuable planetary assests. This alone is fine, but the monsters also patrol neighboring nodes. This gives you an opportunity to siege the asses while the monster is away, but the monster tends to move toward your fleet. This is troublesome when you move onto a node that you don't know is adjacent to a monster's den until it's too late. The monsters are powerful enough to scuttle anything but the strongest fleets, so you may need to kiss that fleet goodbye through no fault of your own.
	Finally, some the late game missions drag on. Most of the missions can be resolved in under an hour, but the final missions can stretch well beyond that, especially if you have to contend with the aforementioned backtracking or monster rampages. Not necessarily a demerit, but something player should be aware of.
	Artwork and UI is clear. I especially like the small touches on the ship desigsn. The rabbits have long ear-like structures, the bees have hex-grid patterns, and the slug ships have bulbous snail shell like structures. Sounds are passable, although the soundtrack is a little parse and some of the sound effects levels are inexplicably loud.
	Although I was initially skeptical and I had some frustration with the fact that losing an early mission before you get a back up commander end your campaign, I found myself seeing the strategic space availble and enjoyed the time I spend with the game. This particularly true on the difficult later levels, where every turn was a demanding struggle to achieve victory. [b] Space Tyrant is accesible enough to appeal to inexperienced strategy players, but maintains enough complexity and challenge to entertain veterans as well. [/b]

It's fun!

A lightweight 4X game that covers the biggest flaws in the 4X genre with elements borrowed from roguelikes.  It neatly dodges the two biggest complaints about 4X games: 1) the AI is bad and 2) the game bogs down in micromanagement.

The AI... well, sure, the AI isn't really competent.  But that's OK!  Victory is not about beating the AI, it's about accomplishing your goals before something goes wrong.  Victory is more like a rogue-lite, where you race against time.  The unrest meter slowly ticking away, planets rebelling, the Senate fleet growing, all these things build up until you just can't go on.  The AI is mostly there to stick a finger in your eye at the worst possible time: Your fleet is finally in position to attack the Senate capital, but suddenly a planet rebels, joins the Senate and puts your homeworld under siege.  Although the difficulty isn't fiendish - at least in the early levels - It is totally possible to lose this game if you're careless or unlucky.  Later on it gets quite a bit harder.  And watch out for the space monsters.

And there's no bogging down, either.  The game plays fast.  The traditional "next turn" button conveniently changes to point you at the next thing you need to deal with, and just about the time when you'd start snowballing to a victory in most 4X games, the game declares the scenario won for you.  The worst thing that can happen is some fleet of yours flies off to a random dead-end world... but even a dead-end fleet in the empire's backwater can be used to boost your economics in a pinch.

The cards are situationally useful, from useless to totally overwhelming and anywhere in between, depending on the luck of the draw and what happens to be on the map.  But they add variety to a game that might otherwise become routine.

Though the game is in early access, it's pretty stable and bugs are few.

This is likely to always be a niche game, but it fills that niche well.  Play it on your lunch break, just be sure to set an alarm because you can end up spending three or four hours before you know it.

33655143.review:
Having played this for a couple of hours now, this game really does eat away at your time in the best possible way! The gameplay is what you'd expect but everything has a certain style that makes you feel like an evil Tyrant, especially when you have your Tyrany meter up so high you can fire off a death laser and save yourself the trouble of dealing with a few enemy ships! Everything about the game makes you comfortable, the music is phenomenal and the pop-culutre references and card designs are both wacky and easy to understand.

The campaign plays quite well and feels like a hyrbid between Endless Space, and a little like Rogue Legacy in terms of humour and replayability. There are still 2 more Campaigns to play through but right now if you like space and conquering worlds this is a fun game that part of me wishes I had a laptop to play on the go too!

There have been no bugs or gameplay issues found so far by me, it does what it says on the tin, you're a Space Tyrant. In Space. Act like it!

33654812.review:
I wish there was a 50/50 button. The gameplay is slick, it's very polished, and it's fun. It also has more depth than meets the eye. That said, when I ask myself whether I want to play this or other 4x games, I will always answer with other ones. The game is not that involved, and I don't get attached to anything I do. This would be really perfect as a mobile game. I don't mean this in a derogatory manner, but I could see myself playing this on a tablet while waiting at the airport etc. However, when I have access to my PC I'd rather play something else. 

Still comes recommended because it's simply a good game. However, nowadays when we're spoiled for choice...'good' doesn't necessarily cut it when I'm considering what game to spend my time on.

Props to the dev though for making such a fun and polished experience.
